title: UST Medical Physics group announces collaboration on advanced dose modeling
dek: A joint effort will develop computational tools for dose calculation, stopping power ratios, and clinically-relevant validation workflows.

author.name: Physics of Life and Stuff Research Group

hero.caption: The project will focus on computational modeling and validation workflows relevant to clinical physics.
hero.credit: Physics of Life and Stuff / UST

content.text: The Physics of Life and Stuff Research Group at the University of Santo Tomas has launched a new collaboration aimed at improving computational dose modeling and validation workflows for medical physics applications.
The work will combine numerical methods with clinically meaningful benchmarks, with initial focus on stopping power ratio modeling and robust comparison against reference datasets.

items: A numerical pipeline for evaluating stopping power ratios under clinically relevant conditions
Validation workflows using phantom-like scenarios and controlled geometry studies
Reproducible documentation and data packaging for future students and collaborators

content.text: We’re designing this to be both mathematically rigorous and clinically interpretable — the goal is to reduce friction between theory, simulation, and practice.
The group will share periodic updates as the collaboration progresses. Interested collaborators may reach out via the contact details on the lab homepage.
